critique: This document concerns the redrawing of boundaries between the Carson National Forest and the Jicarilla Apache Indian Reservation. It aims to restore the reservation to its pre-1909 status, effectively reversing a prior decision to include reservation land within the national forest. This action appears to respect tribal sovereignty and land rights. There is no clear indication of ideological bias, immigration policy, executive power expansion, national security concerns, economic regulation, or social inclusion issues. The federalism aspect is slightly tilted towards state/tribal control as it returns land to the reservation, reducing federal control over that land.
